sub_topic: Quantum computing with nuclear magnetic resonance
message_1: Calculate the probability of measuring the nuclear spin of an atom in the ground state to be "up" after it has been subjected to a 90-degree radiofrequency pulse in a nuclear magnetic resonance experiment. Assume the spin is initially pointing along the z-axis.
message_2:
In a nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) experiment, the nuclear spin of an atom can be manipulated using radiofrequency pulses. When a 90-degree pulse is applied, the spin is rotated from the z-axis to the x-y plane. To calculate the probability of measuring the nuclear spin to be "up" (along the z-axis) after the 90-degree pulse, we can use the principles of quantum mechanics.

The initial state of the nuclear spin along the z-axis can be represented by the spin-up state |ψ⟩ = |+z⟩. After applying the 90-degree pulse, the spin state is rotated to the x-y plane, which can be represented as a superposition of the spin-up and spin-down states:

|ψ'⟩ = (1/√2)|+z⟩ + (1/√2)|-z⟩

Now, we want to calculate the probability of measuring the spin to be "up" (along the z-axis) after the pulse. The probability is given by the square of the amplitude of the spin-up state in the new superposition:

P(+z) = |⟨+z|ψ'⟩|^2

To calculate this, we take the inner product of the spin-up state with the new superposition:

⟨+z|ψ'⟩ = ⟨+z|(1/√2)|+z⟩ + ⟨+z|(1/√2)|-z⟩

Since ⟨+z|+z⟩ = 1 and ⟨+z|-z⟩ = 0, we have:

⟨+z|ψ'⟩ = (1/√2)

Now, we square this amplitude to find the probability:

P(+z) = |(1/√2)|^2 = 1/2

So, the probability of measuring the nuclear spin to be "up" after applying a 90-degree radiofrequency pulse is 1/2 or 50%.
